description: From un- +‎ get; compare unbeget, Middle English ungeten (“unbegotten; not won; not captured”).

verbs.description: unget (third-person singular simple present ungets, present participle ungetting, simple past ungot, past participle ungot or ungotten)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to be unbegotten or unborn, or as if unbegotten or unborn.
examples: I'll disown you, I'll disinherit you, I'll unget you.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To unacquire; relinquish; release; get rid of; lose; lose hold of; forget
examples: He felt himself in the position that having got the conviction he did not see how he was to unget it.
